questions.text: In Class C (Complementary Commutation), how is the commutation achieved?

options.text: By using an external pulse source
By turning on one SCR to commutate the other using a charged capacitor
By letting supply voltage go to zero

questions.text: Which commutation class is most suitable for medium to high power applications?
Why is Class E (External Pulse Commutation) rarely used in practice?

options.text: It is inefficient at low frequency
Due to complexity and high cost of pulse generation

questions.text: Which commutation classes are best suited for high-frequency switching applications?
What is a major limitation of forced commutation circuits?

options.text: They require a low switching frequency
They increase the turn-on time of SCR

questions.text: What does the commutation capacitor do in forced commutation circuits?

options.text: Generates reverse voltage across SCR to turn it off

questions.text: What defines the commutation margin angle (?) in SCR operation?

options.text: Time between SCR turn-on and peak current
Angle between SCR turn-off and zero crossing of voltage
Phase shift between gate and anode current
Time delay between capacitor charging and SCR conduction

questions.text: Why are IGBTs and MOSFETs preferred over SCRs in modern converters?

options.text: They are self-commutating and simplify circuit design

questions.text: In HVDC systems, why is line commutation used with thyristors?

options.text: Because supply voltage naturally reverses for commutation
To avoid using any passive components

questions.text: What can be a result of commutation failure in thyristor-based circuits?

options.text: Overcurrent, circuit malfunction, and disrupted operation

questions.text: What is the torque-speed characteristic of a synchronous motor?

options.text: Flat at synchronous speed with zero torque below it

questions.text: Why are synchronous motors less suitable for variable load applications?

options.text: They lose synchronism under load variation

questions.text: How is power factor controlled in synchronous motors?
What power factor condition does an over-excited synchronous motor exhibit?
What is the function of a synchronous motor when used as a synchronous condenser?

options.text: It supplies reactive power to improve power factor

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE about synchronous reluctance motors?

options.text: They develop torque using rotor saliency
They operate only in generator mode

questions.text: Can synchronous motors operate in generator mode?
How does the load angle affect a synchronous motor's performance?

options.text: A small angle increases power losses
Excessive angle can lead to loss of synchronism

questions.text: Why are synchronous motors preferred in textile and paper industries?

options.text: They are cheaper than induction motors
They provide constant speed under varying load

questions.text: What happens to a synchronous motor when it is under-excited?

options.text: It operates at a leading power factor
It operates at a lagging power factor

questions.text: What distinguishes a Buck-Boost converter from Buck or Boost converters in terms of output polarity?

options.text: Same polarity and only steps down
Same polarity and only steps up
Reversed polarity and can step up or down

questions.text: Where is a Buck-Boost converter most commonly used?

options.text: When constant input and variable output are needed
When input voltage varies but fixed output is needed
When high frequency AC output is required

questions.text: How does a dual converter enable bidirectional power flow?

options.text: By using a single chopper with two switches
By combining buck and boost in one stage
By using two choppers: one for forward and one for reverse

questions.text: What is the role of a freewheeling diode in chopper circuits?

options.text: Provides path for inductor current during OFF state

questions.text: Which component is NOT typically used to protect chopper circuits from voltage spikes?
What is a primary advantage of soft switching over hard switching in chopper circuits?
What is the function of a snubber circuit in a chopper?

options.text: Absorbs inductive energy to prevent voltage spikes

questions.text: Why are MOSFETs preferred in high-frequency chopper circuits?

options.text: High current capacity and slow switching
Faster switching and lower conduction losses

questions.text: What is the main reason Buck converters are used in mobile chargers or power banks?

options.text: To reduce USB voltage efficiently to battery voltage

questions.text: Which of the following best describes hard switching in power electronics?

options.text: Switching occurs at zero current or voltage
Switch turns ON/OFF at peak power for maximum efficiency
High stress and loss due to switching at non-zero conditions

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of commutation in power electronics?

options.text: To increase the voltage across SCRs
To transfer current from one SCR to another and turn off conducting SCRs
To boost the gate signal strength

questions.text: Why can't a conducting thyristor (SCR) be turned off using a gate signal alone?

options.text: SCR requires AC voltage to turn off
SCR latches and remains on until current drops below holding current
Gate signal is not synchronized with supply

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a type of commutation technique in power electronics?
In which scenario is natural commutation typically used?

options.text: In AC to DC converters where supply voltage reverses naturally
In circuits with zero load current

questions.text: Why is forced commutation necessary in DC circuits?

options.text: Because gate signals are ineffective in DC circuits
Because voltage in DC does not naturally reverse

questions.text: Which commutation class uses the load's LC resonance to turn off the SCR?
What is the principle of Class B (Self-Commutation) technique?

options.text: Using LC circuit to reverse voltage across SCR

questions.text: Which class of commutation involves an auxiliary SCR and capacitor?
Which of the following circuits typically employs forced commutation?
In natural commutation, when does the SCR turn off?

options.text: When supply voltage naturally goes to zero

questions.text: What is the function of a commutator in a DC machine?

options.text: Converts AC in the armature to unidirectional DC for external use

questions.text: What is the role of brushes in a DC machine?

options.text: Transfer current between rotating armature and external circuit

questions.text: Why are carbon brushes preferred in DC machines?

options.text: Good lubricating property and reduced sparking

questions.text: On which principle does a DC generator operate?
What is the EMF equation of a DC generator?
What is a separately excited DC generator?

options.text: A generator with no field winding
Field winding is powered by the armature
Field winding is powered by an external DC source
Field winding is powered by AC

questions.text: What is back EMF in a DC motor?
Why should a DC series motor not run without load?

options.text: Speed increases dangerously due to reduced flux

questions.text: What is armature reaction in a DC machine?

options.text: Weakening and distortion of main field flux

questions.text: What is the function of compensation windings in DC machines?
Which of the following methods provides speed control above the rated speed in a DC motor?
Which method is used to decrease the speed of a DC motor below its rated speed?
Which of the following is NOT an advantage of the flux control method?

options.text: Wide speed control above rated speed

questions.text: What is a major disadvantage of the armature resistance control method?

options.text: Poor efficiency due to I?R losses

questions.text: Which DC motor starter has a separate field circuit for better control?
What is the role of the No-volt coil (NVC) in a DC motor starter?

options.text: Prevents automatic restarting after power failure

questions.text: Why are DC series motors preferred in traction applications?
In regenerative braking, a DC motor:
Which of the following is a constant loss in DC machines?
Which of the following is NOT a type of mechanical loss in DC machines?

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of three-phase induction motors?
Why is speed control of three-phase induction motors considered complex?

options.text: Speed remains constant and depends on supply frequency and poles

questions.text: What type of motor is commonly used in domestic appliances?
Which of the following is a type of single-phase induction motor?
Which is a valid speed control method for single-phase induction motors?
Why are induction motors used in ceiling fans instead of DC motors?

options.text: They are more robust and run directly on AC supply

questions.text: What is the role of the capacitor in single-phase induction motors?

options.text: Creates phase difference for rotating field

questions.text: Why are induction motors not suitable for precision speed control?

options.text: They always run at synchronous speed
Speed varies with load due to slip

questions.text: Which starting method is commonly used in single-phase induction motors?
Which of these is NOT a method to control speed in single-phase induction motors?
What principle does a 3-phase induction motor operate on?
What is the effect of increasing the number of poles in a 3-phase induction motor?
How is a rotating magnetic field produced in a 3-phase induction motor?
Which of the following is a key feature of a squirrel cage rotor?
Why are slip rings used in a wound rotor motor?

options.text: To supply power to the stator
To connect rotor winding to external resistance during startup

questions.text: Why is Direct-On-Line (DOL) starting avoided in large motors?
Which statement is true about DOL starting?

options.text: Suitable for small motors due to high starting current

questions.text: What is typically true about the starting torque of an induction motor?

options.text: It is less than or equal to full load torque
It is not affected by slip

questions.text: At what point does maximum torque occur in a torque-slip curve?

options.text: At a specific slip called breakdown slip

questions.text: Why does an induction motor draw more magnetizing current than a transformer?

options.text: Due to presence of air gap
